params.text:
Reading

Understand Notes

Language in Action

• Quickly identify keywords
  • Time markers
  • Review how to read the time
Reading: Introduction

Notes are like little messages. They help us remember things. Let's learn how to read them! 

We will learn to:

1. Find important words quickly

  2. See when things will happen.

  3. Read the time.
Quickly Identify Keywords: Key Points
• Read the first sentence:

• The first sentence often gives you a big idea.
    Example: "The meeting starts at 2 pm." tells you when the meeting is.
• Find big words:

• Big words are often important.
    Example: "Meeting" is a big word that tells you about people talking together.
• Think about the picture:

• A picture can help you understand.
    Example: A picture of people talking means the text is about a meeting.

Important words help you understand the text.
Here's how to find them:
• Look at the title:

• The title tells you what the text is about.
    Example: A text with the title "Office Meeting" is about a meeting

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What is taking place next week?
answers:
Renovations in the office

A training session

A big meeting

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: When will the renovations be finished?
Question 3 of 3: Where can people work if they don’t want to work at home?
answers:
The second office in La Defense

At the manager’s house

On the beach

params.text: Quickly Identify Keywords: Reading and Quiz
Please read the following text and answer the questions:

Dear all,

There are planned renovations taking place in the office next week. This will cause some disruption to work. The renovation work will take place from May 21st until June 10th. During that time, you can either work from home, or you can work at our second office in La Defense.

Please inform Human Resources of your choice by May 17th, by emailing hr@rosetrading.com

Thank you for your assistance.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What training will happen from next month?
Question 2 of 3: When will the classes NOT take place?
Question 3 of 3: How can employees sign-up for the training?
answers:
By emailing the training department

By arriving on Tuesday morning to class

By contacting their manager

params.text: Quickly Identify Keywords: Reading and Quiz
Please read the following text and answer the questions:

Dear all,
I am happy to announce a fantastic training opportunity for our employees. From next month, you will have access to group English lessons at the office. Classes will take place on Tuesday and Wednesday mornings.

If you are interested, please contact the training department by Friday, by emailing training@rosetrading.com
Time markers: Key Points
• Check the numbers:

• Numbers with days or months are time clues.
    Example: "The meeting is on Monday.
• See the clock:

• Times like "2 pm" or "10:30 am" are time clues.
    Example: "The movie starts at 7 pm."
• Read the whole sentence:

• Sometimes, the whole sentence tells you when.
    Example: "We will have a party next week."

Time words are like clues in a story. They tell you when things happen.
Here's how to find them:
• Look for special words:

• Words like "today," "tomorrow," and "next week" tell you the time.
    Example: "I will see you tomorrow.

Question 2 of 3: Who says the time out loud to remember?
Question 3 of 3: Who thinks about their own clock at home?

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.

metadata.title: Review How To Read The Time 1 Quiz

params.text: Dialogue Text:

Micah: I look at the two hands. The short one is the hour and the long one is the minutes. It's easy!
Abigail: I say the time out loud. It helps me remember. For example, "two thirty".
Bryan: I think of a clock in my room. It helps me see the time in my head.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What do Anthony and Bryan think is difficult about emails?
Question 2 of 3: How do they understand the time?
answers:
By looking at the clock hands

By reading a book

By listening to music

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What do they say after they see the clock hands?

metadata.title: Review How To Read The Time Conversation 2 Quiz

params.text: Review How To Read The Time: Listening and Quiz
Please listen to the conversation between Bryan and Anthony, and answer the questions below:
Anthony:
Bryan:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Anthony: Emails are hard. Time is tricky.

Bryan: Yes, they are! I look at the big and small hands on the clock.

Anthony: Me too. Then I say the time like "two thirty" or "ten past twelve".

Bryan: That's right. It's easier to understand.

Anthony: Sometimes the words are hard too.

Bryan: Yes, like "am" and "pm".
Dialogue Text:
Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 5: What helps you know what the note is about?
Question 2 of 5: What do you do when you see a number and a day together?
answers:
Think about the time

Think about the weather

Think about food

choices.question: Question 3 of 5: Why are important words helpful?
answers:
They tell you the main idea

They are fun to say

They are short

choices.question: Question 4 of 5: What should you do if you don't understand a word?
answers:
Guess the meaning

Ask a friend

Skip the word

choices.question: Question 5 of 5: Why is it important to read notes carefully?
answers:
To understand the message

To look at the pictures

To find mistakes
